message_1:
Here's a precise numerical problem for a math student in model theory:

Let L be a first-order language consisting of a binary relation symbol < and a unary function symbol f. Let T be the complete theory of the structure M = <Z, <, f> where Z is the set of integers, < is the usual ordering on Z, and f is the function sending each integer n to n+1.

Find the number of models up to isomorphism of cardinality |Z| (=the cardinality of the set of integers) that are elementary equivalent to M.
message_2:
To find the number of models up to isomorphism of cardinality |Z| that are elementary equivalent to M, we can use the Löwenheim-Skolem theorem and the concept of elementary chains.

First, note that M is countable since it is a structure over the set of integers. By the Löwenheim-Skolem theorem, any countable theory has a countable model. Since T is the complete theory of M, any countable model of T will be elementary equivalent to M.

Now, consider an elementary chain of countable models of T:

M₀ ≺ M₁ ≺ M₂ ≺ ...

where each model Mᵢ is an elementary submodel of Mᵢ₊₁. By the Löwenheim-Skolem theorem, we can find such a chain of countable models. Moreover, the union of this chain is also a model of T:

M' = ⋃ Mᵢ

Since each Mᵢ is countable, M' is also countable. Furthermore, M' is elementary equivalent to M since it is a model of T.

Now, we claim that there are ℵ₀ (aleph-null) non-isomorphic models of cardinality |Z| that are elementary equivalent to M. To see this, note that for each Mᵢ in the elementary chain, there is an integer nᵢ such that Mᵢ is isomorphic to the structure <Z, <, f> where f is the function sending each integer n to n+nᵢ. Since there are ℵ₀ such integers nᵢ, there are ℵ₀ non-isomorphic models in the elementary chain.

Thus, there are ℵ₀ (aleph-null) models up to isomorphism of cardinality |Z| that are elementary equivalent to M.
